# Red-tailed hawk

Red-tailed hawk

The **red-tailed hawk** (_Buteo jamaicensis_) is a [bird of
prey](/wiki/Bird_of_prey "Bird of prey"), one of three species colloquially
known in the United States as the "[chickenhawk](/wiki/Chickenhawk_\(bird\)
"Chickenhawk \(bird\)")," though it rarely preys on standard-sized
chickens.[2] It breeds throughout most of North America, from western
[Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska") and northern [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada")
to as far south as [Panama](/wiki/Panama "Panama") and the [West
Indies](/wiki/West_Indies "West Indies"), and is one of the most common
[buteos](/wiki/Buteo "Buteo") in [North America](/wiki/North_America "North
America"). Red-tailed hawks can acclimate to all the [biomes](/wiki/Biome
"Biome") within their range. The 14 recognized subspecies vary in appearance
and range. It is one of the largest members of the genus _[Buteo](/wiki/Buteo
"Buteo")_ in North America, typically weighing from 690 to 1,600 g (1.5 to 3.5
lb) and measuring 45–65 cm (18–26 in) in length, with a wingspan from 110–145
cm (43–57 in). The red-tailed hawk displays [sexual
dimorphism](/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism "Sexual dimorphism") in size, with females
averaging about 25% heavier than males.[3] The bird is sometimes referred to
as the **red-tail** for short, when the meaning is clear in context.

The subspecies **Harlan 's hawk** (_B. j. harlani_) is sometimes considered a
separate species (_B. harlani_).[4]

The red-tailed hawk occupies a wide range of habitats and altitudes including
deserts, grasslands, [coniferous](/wiki/Coniferous "Coniferous") and
[deciduous](/wiki/Deciduous "Deciduous") forests, agricultural fields and
urban areas. It lives throughout the North American continent, except in areas
of unbroken forest or the [high arctic](/wiki/Arctic "Arctic"). It is legally
protected in Canada, Mexico and the United States by the [Migratory Bird
Treaty Act](/wiki/Migratory_Bird_Treaty_Act "Migratory Bird Treaty Act").

Because they are so common and easily trained as capable hunters, the majority
of hawks captured for [falconry](/wiki/Falconry "Falconry") in the United
States are red-tails. Falconers are permitted to take only passage hawks
(which have left the nest, are on their own, but are less than a year old) so
as to not affect the breeding population. Adults, which may be breeding or
rearing chicks, may not be taken for falconry purposes and it is illegal to do
so. Passage red-tailed hawks are also preferred by falconers because these
younger birds have not yet developed the adult behaviors which would make them
more difficult to train.

## Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

As is the case with many raptors, the red-tailed hawk displays [sexual
dimorphism](/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism "Sexual dimorphism") in size, as females
are up to 25% larger than males.[5] As is typical in large raptors, frequently
reported mean body mass for Red-tailed Hawks are somewhat higher than
expansive research reveals.[6] Part of this weight is highly seasonally
variable and due to clinal variation, male red-tailed hawks may weigh from 690
to 1,300 g (1.52 to 2.87 lb) and in females between 900 and 2,000 g (2.0 and
4.4 lb). However, research from nine studies occurring at migration sites in
the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") and two breeding
studies, one from the smallest race in [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto
Rico"), the other from larger races in [Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin
"Wisconsin") show that males weigh a mean of 837 g (1.845 lb) and females
weigh a mean of 1,040.7 g (2.294 lb), about 15% lighter than prior species-
wide published weights.[6][7][8] The heaviest surveyed weights came from
migrants in [Cape May, New Jersey](/wiki/Cape_May,_New_Jersey "Cape May, New
Jersey"), where females weighed a mean of 1,278 g (2.818 lb), males a mean of
990.8 g (2.184 lb).[7] The lightest were from the breeding population in
forest openings of [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), where the
females and males weighed an average of 1,023 g (2.255 lb) and 795 g (1.753
lb), respectively, also the highest size sexual dimorphism in the species.
Size variation in body mass reveals that the red-tailed hawks typically varies
only a modest amount, racial variation in average weights of [great horned
owls](/wiki/Great_horned_owl "Great horned owl") show that mean body mass is
nearly twice (the heaviest race is about 36% heavier than the lightest known
race on average) as variable as that of the hawk (where the heaviest race is
only just over 18% heavier on average than the lightest).[7][8][9] Males can
reportedly measure 45 to 60 cm (18 to 24 in) in total length, females
measuring 48 to 65 cm (19 to 26 in) long. The wingspan can range from 105 to
141 cm (41 to 56 in) and, in the standard scientific method of measuring wing
size, the [wing chord](/wiki/Wing_chord_\(biology\) "Wing chord \(biology\)")
is 325.1–444.5 mm (12.80–17.50 in) long. The tail measures 188 to 258.7 mm
(7.40 to 10.19 in) in length.[10][11] The [exposed
culmen](/wiki/Culmen_\(bird\) "Culmen \(bird\)") was reported to range from
21.7 to 30.2 mm (0.85 to 1.19 in) and the [tarsus](/wiki/Tarsus_\(skeleton\)
"Tarsus \(skeleton\)") averaged 74.7–95.8 mm (2.94–3.77 in).[6][7][12] The
middle toe (excluding talon) can range from 38.3 to 53.8 mm (1.51 to 2.12 in),
with the hallux-claw (the talon of the rear toe, which has evolved to be the
largest in accipitrids) measuring from 24.1 to 33.6 mm (0.95 to 1.32 in) in
length.[6][7]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/RedTailDisplay.jpg/170px-
RedTailDisplay.jpg)](/wiki/File:RedTailDisplay.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RedTailDisplay.jpg "Enlarge")

Characteristic red tail

Red-tailed hawk [plumage](/wiki/Plumage "Plumage") can be variable, depending
on the [subspecies](/wiki/Subspecies "Subspecies") and the region. These color
variations are [morphs](/wiki/Polymorphism_\(biology\) "Polymorphism
\(biology\)"), and are not related to [molting](/wiki/Molt "Molt"). The
western North American population, _B. j. calurus_ , is the most variable
subspecies and has three color morphs: light, dark, and intermediate or rufus.
The dark and intermediate morphs constitute 10–20% of the population.[13]

Though the markings and hue vary across the subspecies, the basic appearance
of the red-tailed hawk is consistent. Overall, this species is blocky and
broad in shape, often appearing (and being) heavier than other
_[Buteos](/wiki/Buteo "Buteo")_ of similar length.[10] A whitish underbelly
with a dark brown band across the belly, formed by horizontal streaks in
[feather](/wiki/Feather "Feather") patterning, is present in most color
variations. Especially in younger birds, the underside may be otherwise
covered with dark brown spotting. The red tail, which gives this species its
name, is uniformly brick-red above and light buff-orange below.[10][14] The
[bill](/wiki/Beak "Beak") is short and dark, in the hooked shape
characteristic of [raptors](/wiki/Bird_of_prey "Bird of prey"), and the head
can sometimes appear small in size against the thick body frame.[10] They have
a relatively short, broad tails and thick, chunky wings.[14] The
[cere](/wiki/Cere "Cere"), the legs, and the feet of the red-tailed hawk are
all yellow.[5]

Immature birds can be readily identified at close range by their yellowish
[irises](/wiki/Iris_\(anatomy\) "Iris \(anatomy\)"). As the bird attains full
maturity over the course of 3–4 years, the iris slowly darkens into a reddish-
brown hue. In both the light and dark morphs, the tail of the immature red-
tailed hawk is patterned with numerous darker bars.[14]

"Edit section: Taxonomy")]

Red-tailed hawk hovers in the wind

The red-tailed hawk is a member of the [genus](/wiki/Genus "Genus")
_[Buteo](/wiki/Buteo "Buteo")_ , a group of medium-sized raptors with robust
bodies and broad wings. Members of this genus are known as _buzzards_ in
Europe, but _hawks_ in North America.[15]

There are at least 14 recognized subspecies of _Buteo jamaicensis_ , which
vary in range and in coloration:

  * _B. j. jamaicensis_ , the nominate subspecies, occurs in the northern [West Indies](/wiki/West_Indies "West Indies"), including [Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica"), [Hispaniola](/wiki/Hispaniola "Hispaniola"), [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") and the [Lesser Antilles](/wiki/Lesser_Antilles "Lesser Antilles") but not the [Bahamas](/wiki/Bahamas "Bahamas") or [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"). [El Yunque National Forest](/wiki/El_Yunque_National_Forest "El Yunque National Forest"), [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") holds the highest known density of red-tailed hawks anywhere.[16] The bird is referred to as "Guaraguao" in the island.[17][18]
  * _B. j. alascensis_ breeds (probably resident) from southeastern coastal [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska") to the [Queen Charlotte Islands](/wiki/Queen_Charlotte_Islands "Queen Charlotte Islands") and [Vancouver Island](/wiki/Vancouver_Island "Vancouver Island") in British Columbia.[19]
  * _B. j. borealis_ group[20] (eastern red-tailed hawk)[20] breeds from southeast Canada and [Maine](/wiki/Maine "Maine") south through eastern Texas and east to northern Florida. It winters from southern Ontario east to southern Maine and south to the Gulf coast and Florida.[19]
  * _B. j. calurus_ (western red-tailed hawk)[20] breeds from central interior [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska"), through western Canada south to Baja California. It winters from southwestern [British Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia") southwest to [Guatemala](/wiki/Guatemala "Guatemala") and northern [Nicaragua](/wiki/Nicaragua "Nicaragua").[19] Paler individuals of northern Mexico may lack the dark wing marking.[21]
  * _B. j. costaricensis_ is resident from [Nicaragua](/wiki/Nicaragua "Nicaragua") to [Panama](/wiki/Panama "Panama"). This subspecies is dark brown above with cinnamon flanks, wing linings and sides, and some birds have rufous underparts. The chest is much less heavily streaked than in northern migrants (_B. j. calurus_) to Central America.
  * _B. j. fuertesi_ (southwestern red-tailed hawk)[20] breeds from northern [Chihuahua](/wiki/Chihuahua_\(state\) "Chihuahua \(state\)") to southern Texas. It winters in [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"), and southern [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana").[19] The belly is unstreaked or only lightly streaked, and the tail is pale.
  * _B. j. fumosus_ , [Islas Marías](/wiki/Islas_Mar%C3%ADas "Islas Marías"), Mexico
  * _B. j. hadropus_ , Mexican Highlands
  * _B. j. harlani_ (Harlan's red-tailed hawk,[20] sometimes classified as its own species, _B. harlani_ , Harlan's hawk[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]) is markedly different from all other red-tails. In both color morphs, the plumage is blackish and white, lacking warm tones (save the tail). The tail may be reddish, dusky, whitish, or gray and can be longitudinally streaked, mottled, or barred. Shorter primaries result in wingtips that don't reach the tail in perched birds. It breeds in Alaska and northwestern Canada and winters from [Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska") and [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas") to Texas and northern [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana").[19] This population may well be a separate species.
  * _B. j. kemsiesi_ is a dark subspecies resident from [Chiapas](/wiki/Chiapas "Chiapas") to [Nicaragua](/wiki/Nicaragua "Nicaragua"). The dark wing marking may not be distinct in paler birds.[21]
  * _B. j. kriderii_ (Krider's red-tailed hawk)[20] is paler than other red-tails, especially on the head; the tail may be pinkish or white. In the breeding season, it occurs from southern Alberta, southern Saskatchewan, southern Manitoba, and extreme western Ontario south to south-central Montana, Wyoming, western Nebraska, and western Minnesota. In winter, it occurs from South Dakota and southern Minnesota south to Arizona, New Mexico, Texas and Louisiana.[19]
  * _B. j. socorroensis_ , [Socorro Island](/wiki/Socorro_Island "Socorro Island"), Mexico
  * _B. j. solitudinus_ , Bahamas and Cuba
  * _B. j. umbrinus_ occurs year-round in peninsular Florida north to [Tampa Bay](/wiki/Tampa_Bay "Tampa Bay") and the Kissimmee Prairie.[19] It is similar in appearance to _calurus_

The four island forms, _jamaicensis_ , _solitudinus_ , _socorroensis_ , and
_fumosus_ , do not overlap in range with any other subspecies.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Red_Tailed_Hawk_Stare.jpg/220px-
Red_Tailed_Hawk_Stare.jpg)](/wiki/File:Red_Tailed_Hawk_Stare.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Red_Tailed_Hawk_Stare.jpg "Enlarge")

A juvenile red-tailed hawk

The red-tailed hawk is one of the most widely scattered hawks in the Americas.
It breeds from central [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska"), the
[Yukon](/wiki/Yukon "Yukon"), and the [Northwest
Territories](/wiki/Northwest_Territories "Northwest Territories") east to
southern [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") and the [Maritime
Provinces](/wiki/Maritime_Provinces "Maritime Provinces") of Canada, and south
to Florida, the [West Indies](/wiki/West_Indies "West Indies"), and Central
America. The winter range stretches from southern Canada south throughout the
remainder of the breeding range.[19]

Its preferred habitat is mixed forest and field, with high bluffs or trees
that may be used as perch sites. It occupies a wide range of
[habitats](/wiki/Habitat_\(ecology\) "Habitat \(ecology\)") and altitudes,
including deserts, grasslands, coastal regions, mountains, foothills,
[coniferous](/wiki/Coniferous "Coniferous") and [deciduous](/wiki/Deciduous
"Deciduous") woodlands, [tropical rainforests](/wiki/Tropical_rainforest
"Tropical rainforest"), [agricultural fields](/wiki/Field_\(agriculture\)
"Field \(agriculture\)") and urban areas.[1] It is second only to the
[peregrine falcon](/wiki/Peregrine_falcon "Peregrine falcon") in the use of
diverse habitats in North America.[22] It lives throughout the North American
continent, except in areas of unbroken forest or the high Arctic.[13]

Adult hawks have few natural predators, although their eggs and chicks are
preyed on by a variety of organisms. The red-tailed hawk is widespread in
North America,[22] partially due to historic settlement patterns, which have
benefited it. The clearing of forests in the Northeast created hunting areas,
while the preservation of [woodlots](/wiki/Woodlot "Woodlot") left the species
with viable nest sites. The increase in trees throughout the Great Plains
during the past century due to fire suppression and tree planting facilitated
the western range expansion of the red-tailed hawk[23] as well as range
expansions of many other species of birds.[24][25][26] The construction of
highways with [utility poles](/wiki/Utility_pole "Utility pole") alongside
treeless medians provided perfect habitat for perch-hunting. Unlike some other
raptors, the red-tailed hawk are seemingly unfazed by considerable human
activity and can nest and live in close proximity to large numbers of
humans.[10] Thus, the species can also be found in cities, where common prey
such as [rock pigeons](/wiki/Rock_pigeon "Rock pigeon") and [brown
rats](/wiki/Brown_rat "Brown rat") may support their populations.[27] One
famous urban red-tailed hawk, known as "[Pale Male](/wiki/Pale_Male "Pale
Male")", became the subject of a non-fiction book, _Red-Tails in Love: A
Wildlife Drama in Central Park_ , and is the first known red-tail in decades
to successfully nest and raise young in the crowded [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") borough of
[Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan").[28][29][30]

Hawks in urban areas are threatened by the use of rat traps and poisoned bait
to kill rodents. This generally consists of [warfarin](/wiki/Warfarin
"Warfarin") cookies which induce internal bleeding in rats and mice, and a
hawk that ingests rodents who have consumed rat poison can itself be
affected.[31]

## Behavior[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Behavior")]

### Flight[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Flight")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Red-
tailed_Hawk_%28Audubon%29.jpg/170px-Red-
tailed_Hawk_%28Audubon%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Red-tailed_Hawk_\(Audubon\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Red-tailed_Hawk_\(Audubon\).jpg "Enlarge")

Red-tailed hawks engaging in an inflight battle over prey. Painted by [John
James Audubon](/wiki/John_James_Audubon "John James Audubon").

In flight, this hawk soars with wings often in a slight
[dihedral](/wiki/Dihedral_angle "Dihedral angle"), flapping as little as
possible to conserve energy. Active flight is slow and deliberate, with deep
wing beats. In wind, it occasionally hovers on beating wings and remains
stationary above the ground.[13] When soaring or flapping its wings, it
typically travels from 32 to 64 km/h (40 mph), but when diving may exceed 190
km/h (120 mph).[32]

### Vocalization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-
tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Vocalization")]

The cry of the red-tailed hawk is a two to three second hoarse, rasping
scream, described as _kree-eee-ar_ ,[27] that begins at a high pitch and slurs
downward.[32] This cry is often described as sounding similar to a steam
whistle.[5] The red-tailed hawk frequently vocalizes while hunting or soaring,
but vocalizes loudest in annoyance or anger, in response to a predator or a
rival hawk's intrusion into its territory.[27] At close range, it makes a
croaking "guh-runk".[33] Young hawks may utter a wailing _klee-uk_ food cry
when parents leave the nest.[34] The fierce, screaming cry of the red-tailed
hawk is frequently used as a generic raptor sound effect in television shows
and other media, even if the bird featured is not a red-tailed hawk.[35][36]

### Diet[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Diet")]

The red-tailed hawk is [carnivorous](/wiki/Carnivorous "Carnivorous"), and an
opportunistic feeder. Their most common prey are small mammals such as rodents
and lagomorphs, but they will also consume birds, fish, reptiles, and
amphibians. Prey varies with regional and seasonal availability, but usually
centers on [rodents](/wiki/Rodent "Rodent"), comprising up to 85% of a hawk's
diet.[5] Most commonly reported prey types include [mice](/wiki/Mouse
"Mouse"), including both native _[Peromyscus](/wiki/Peromyscus "Peromyscus")_
species and [house mice](/wiki/House_mouse "House mouse");
[gophers](/wiki/Pocket_gopher "Pocket gopher"), [voles](/wiki/Vole "Vole"),
[chipmunks](/wiki/Chipmunk "Chipmunk"), [ground
squirrels](/wiki/Ground_squirrel "Ground squirrel") and [tree
squirrels](/wiki/Tree_squirrel "Tree squirrel").[37][38] Additional prey
(listed by descending likelihood of predation) include
[lagomorphs](/wiki/Lagomorph "Lagomorph"), [shrews](/wiki/Shrew "Shrew"),
[bats](/wiki/Bat "Bat"),[39] [pigeons](/wiki/Pigeon "Pigeon"),
[quail](/wiki/Quail "Quail"), [corvids](/wiki/Corvid "Corvid"),
[waterfowl](/wiki/Waterfowl "Waterfowl"), other [raptors](/wiki/Birds_of_prey
"Birds of prey"), [reptiles](/wiki/Reptile "Reptile"), [fish](/wiki/Fish
"Fish"), [crustaceans](/wiki/Crustacean "Crustacean"), [insects](/wiki/Insect
"Insect") and [earthworms](/wiki/Earthworm "Earthworm").[10] Where found in
[Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") islands, red-tailed hawks prey mostly
on [reptiles](/wiki/Reptile "Reptile") such as [snakes](/wiki/Snake "Snake")
and [lizards](/wiki/Lizard "Lizard"), since these are perhaps the most
predominant native land animals of that region.[10] Prey specimens can range
to as small a size as [beetles](/wiki/Beetle "Beetle") and worms. However,
they can also prey on [marmots](/wiki/Marmot "Marmot"), [white-tailed
jackrabbits](/wiki/White-tailed_jackrabbit "White-tailed jackrabbit"), or
female [wild turkey](/wiki/Wild_turkey "Wild turkey"), all of which are at
least easily double the weight of most red-tails.[10] Hawks will eat
[carrion](/wiki/Carrion "Carrion") if need be, although it is not a preferred
food source. During winter in captivity, an average red-tail will eat about
135 g (4.8 oz) daily.[34]

![File:Red-tailed Hawk Eating a Rodent 1080p
60fps.ogv](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Red-
tailed_Hawk_Eating_a_Rodent_1080p_60fps.ogv/220px-seek%3D12-Red-
tailed_Hawk_Eating_a_Rodent_1080p_60fps.ogv.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a9/Red-
tailed_Hawk_Eating_a_Rodent_1080p_60fps.ogv "Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Red-tailed_Hawk_Eating_a_Rodent_1080p_60fps.ogv "Enlarge")

Red-tailed hawk eating a rodent

The red-tailed hawk commonly employs one of two hunting techniques. Often,
they scan for prey activity from an elevated perch site, swooping down from
the perch to seize the prey. They also watch for prey while flying, either
capturing a bird in flight or pursuing prey on the ground until they can pin
them down in their talons.[10] Red-tailed hawks, like some other raptors, have
been observed to hunt in pairs. This may consist of stalking opposites sides
of a tree, in order to surround a tree squirrel and almost inevitably drive
the rodent to be captured by one after being flushed by the other hawk.[40]
They are opportunistically attracted to conspicuous meals, such as displaying
male [red-winged blackbirds](/wiki/Red-winged_blackbird "Red-winged
blackbird").[5]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Redtailedhawkeatingsquirrel07.jpg/220px-
Redtailedhawkeatingsquirrel07.jpg)](/wiki/File:Redtailedhawkeatingsquirrel07.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Redtailedhawkeatingsquirrel07.jpg "Enlarge")

Juvenile eating a squirrel

The [great horned owl](/wiki/Great_horned_owl "Great horned owl") occupies a
similar [ecological niche](/wiki/Ecological_niche "Ecological niche")
nocturnally to the red-tail, taking similar prey. Competition may occur
between the hawk and [owl](/wiki/Owl "Owl") species during twilight, although
the differing nesting season and activity times usually results in a lack of
direct competition. Although the red-tail's prey is on average larger (due in
part to the scarcity of diurnal [squirrels](/wiki/Squirrel "Squirrel") in the
owl's diet),[38] the owl is an occasional predator of red-tailed hawks
themselves, of any age, while the hawks are not known to predate adult great
horned owls.[37] Other competitors include other large _[Buteo](/wiki/Buteo
"Buteo")_ species such as [Swainson's hawks](/wiki/Swainson%27s_hawk
"Swainson's hawk") and [rough-legged hawks](/wiki/Rough-legged_hawk "Rough-
legged hawk"), as well as the [northern goshawk](/wiki/Northern_goshawk
"Northern goshawk"), since prey and foraging methods of these species
occasionally overlap.[41][42] Hawks have been observed following [American
badgers](/wiki/American_badger "American badger") to capture prey they flush
and the two are considered potential competitors.[43] Competition over
carcasses may occur with [American crows](/wiki/American_crow "American
crow"), and several crows working together can displace a hawk.[44] Larger
raptors, such as [eagles](/wiki/Eagle "Eagle") and [ferruginous
hawks](/wiki/Ferruginous_hawk "Ferruginous hawk"), may steal hawk kills.[5]

### Reproduction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-
tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Reproduction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Courting_redtails.JPG/170px-
Courting_redtails.JPG)](/wiki/File:Courting_redtails.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Courting_redtails.JPG "Enlarge")

Territorial adult chasing away an immature red-tailed hawk

The red-tailed hawk reaches [sexual maturity](/wiki/Sexual_maturity "Sexual
maturity") at two years of age. It is [monogamous](/wiki/Monogamous
"Monogamous"), mating with the same individual for many years. In general, the
red-tailed hawk will only take a new mate when its original mate dies.[45] The
same nesting territory may be defended by the pair for years. During
courtship, the male and female fly in wide circles while uttering shrill
cries. The male performs aerial displays, diving steeply, and then climbing
again. After repeating this display several times, he sometimes grasps her
[talons](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/talon
"wikt:Special:Search/talon") briefly with his own. Courtship flights can last
10 minutes or more. Copulation often follows courtship flight sequences,
although copulation frequently occurs in the absence of courtship flights.

In copulation, the female, when perched, tilts forward, allowing the male to
land with his feet lodged on her horizontal back. The female twists and moves
her tail feathers to one side, while the mounted male twists his cloacal
opening around the female's cloaca. Copulation lasts 5 to 10 seconds and
during pre-nesting courtship in late winter or early spring can occur numerous
times each day.[46]

In the same period, the pair constructs a stick [nest](/wiki/Bird_nest "Bird
nest") in a large tree 4 to 21 m (13 to 69 ft) off the ground or on a cliff
ledge 35 m (115 ft) or higher above the ground, or may nest on man-made
structures. The nest is generally 71 to 97 cm (28 to 38 in) in diameter and
can be up to 90 cm (3.0 ft) tall. The nest is constructed of twigs, and lined
with [bark](/wiki/Bark "Bark"), pine needles, [corn cobs](/wiki/Corn_cob "Corn
cob"), husks, stalks, [aspen](/wiki/Aspen "Aspen") catkins, or other plant
lining matter.

Great horned owls compete with the red-tailed hawk for nest sites. Each
species has been known to kill the young and destroy the eggs of the other,
but in general, both species nest in adjacent or confluent territories without
conflict. Great horned owls are incapable of constructing nests and typically
expropriate existing red-tail nests. Great horned owls begin nesting behaviors
much earlier than red-tails, often as early as December. Red-tails are
therefore adapted to constructing new nests when a previous year's nest has
been overtaken by owls or otherwise lost. New nests are typically within a
kilometer or less of the previous nest. Often, a new nest is only a few
hundred meters or less from a previous one. Being a large predator, most
predation of these hawks occurs with eggs and nestlings, which are taken by
[owls](/wiki/Owl "Owl"), [corvids](/wiki/Corvid "Corvid") and
[raccoons](/wiki/Raccoon "Raccoon").[47]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/RT_hawks.jpg/220px-
RT_hawks.jpg)](/wiki/File:RT_hawks.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RT_hawks.jpg "Enlarge")

Parent in nest with chicks

A clutch of one to three [eggs](/wiki/Egg "Egg") is laid in March or April,
depending upon latitude. Clutch size depends almost exclusively on the
availability of prey for the adults. Eggs are laid approximately every other
day. The eggs are usually about 60 mm × 47 mm (2.4 in × 1.9 in). They are
[incubated](/wiki/Avian_incubation "Avian incubation") primarily by female,
with the male substituting when the female leaves to hunt or merely stretch
her wings. The male brings most food to the female while she incubates. After
28 to 35 days, the eggs hatch over 2 to 4 days; the nestlings are
[altricial](/wiki/Altricial "Altricial") at hatching. The female broods them
while the male provides most of the food to the female and the young, which
are known as eyasses (pronounced "EYE-ess-ez"). The female feeds the eyasses
after tearing the food into small pieces. After 42 to 46 days, the eyasses
begin to leave the nest. The [fledging](/wiki/Fledge "Fledge") period follows,
with short flights engaged in, after another 3 weeks. About 6 to 7 weeks after
fledging, the young begin to capture their own prey. Shortly thereafter, when
the young are around 4 months of age, they become independent of their
parents. However, the hawks do not generally reach breeding maturity until
they are around 3 years of age. In the wild, red-tailed hawks have lived for
at least 25 years, for example, [Pale Male](/wiki/Pale_Male "Pale Male") was
born in 1990, and in Spring 2014 is still raising eyasses. The oldest captive
hawk of this species was at least 29 and a half years of age.[5]

## Relationship with humans[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-
tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Relationship with humans")]

See also § Distribution and habitat, for habitat relationships to human
settlement patterns.

### Use in falconry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-
tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Use in falconry")]

The red-tailed hawk is a popular bird in [falconry](/wiki/Falconry
"Falconry"), particularly in the United States where the sport of falconry is
tightly regulated and where red-tailed hawks are both widely available and
allowed to novice falconers. Red-tailed hawks are highly tameable and
trainable, with a more social disposition than all other falcons or hawks
other than the [Harris's hawk](/wiki/Harris%27s_hawk "Harris's hawk").[48]
They are also long lived and highly disease resistant, allowing a falconer to
maintain a red-tailed hawk as a hunting companion for many years. There are
fewer than 5,000 falconers in the United States, so despite their popularity
any effect on the red-tailed hawk population, estimated to be about one
million in the United States, is negligible.[49]

Not being as swift as [falcons](/wiki/Falcon "Falcon") or
[accipiters](/wiki/Accipiter "Accipiter"), red-tailed hawks are not the most
effective of bird hawks and are usually used against ground game such as
rabbits and squirrels. However, some individuals may learn to ambush birds on
the ground with a swift surprise approach and capture them before they can
accelerate to full speed and escape. Some have even learned to use a falcon-
like diving stoop to capture challenging game such as pheasants. In the course
of a typical hunt, a falconer using a red-tailed hawk most commonly releases
the hawk and allows it to perch in a tree or other high vantage point. The
falconer, who may be aided by a dog, then attempts to
[flush](/wiki/Hunting#Methods "Hunting") prey by stirring up ground cover. A
well-trained red-tailed hawk will follow the falconer and dog, realizing that
their activities produce opportunities to catch game. Once a raptor catches
game, it does not bring it back to the falconer. Instead, the falconer must
locate the bird and its captured prey, "make in" (carefully approach) and
trade the bird its kill in exchange for a piece of offered meat.[50]

### Feathers and Native American use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Red-
tailed_hawk&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Feathers and Native American
use")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Red-
Tailed_Hawk_%2829478965112%29.jpg/220px-Red-
Tailed_Hawk_%2829478965112%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Red-
Tailed_Hawk_\(29478965112\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Red-Tailed_Hawk_\(29478965112\).jpg "Enlarge")

Red-tailed hawk in [Oregon](/wiki/Oregon "Oregon")

The [feathers](/wiki/Feather "Feather") and other parts of the red-tailed hawk
are considered [sacred](/wiki/Sacred "Sacred") to many American [indigenous
people](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples "Indigenous peoples") and, like the feathers
of the [bald eagle](/wiki/Bald_eagle "Bald eagle") and [golden
eagle](/wiki/Golden_eagle "Golden eagle"), are sometimes used in religious
ceremonies and found adorning the [regalia](/wiki/Regalia "Regalia") of many
[Native Americans in the United
States](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the
United States"); these parts, most especially their distinctive tail feathers,
are a popular item in the Native American community.[51] As with the other two
species, the feathers and parts of the red-tailed hawk are regulated by the
[eagle feather law](/wiki/Eagle_feather_law "Eagle feather law"),[52] which
governs the possession of feathers and parts of migratory birds.[53]
